4.1 Vector Spaces and Subspaces

Vector Space

A nonempty set VVV﻿of vectors satisfying the following conditions for u,v∈Vu,v \in Vu,v∈V﻿:

Example: The set of polynomials PnP_nPn​﻿ of degree n≥0n\geq 0n≥0﻿

This set has the zero polynomial

It is closed under vector addition

and scalar multiplication

Subspace

HHH﻿ is a subspace of VVV﻿ if it satisfies:

  • The zero vector of VVV﻿ is in HHH﻿
  • HHH﻿ is closed under vector addition
  • HHH﻿ is closed under scalar multiplication

Example: {0⃗}⊂V\{\vec 0 \} \sub V{0}⊂V﻿

The set consisting of only the zero vector in a vector space VVV﻿ is a subspace of VVV﻿, called the zero subspace.

Theorem 1

If v1,…,vpv_1,\dots,v_pv1​,…,vp​﻿ are in a vector space VVV﻿, then Span{v1,…,vp}\text{Span}\{v_1,\dots,v_p\}Span{v1​,…,vp​}﻿ is a subspace of VVV﻿

Example: Let H=Span{v1,v2}H = \text{Span}\{v_1,v_2\}H=Span{v1​,v2​}﻿

We know HHH﻿ is a subspace of VVV﻿ by Theorem 1.

4.2 Null Spaces, Column Spaces, Row Spaces, and Linear Transformations

Null Space (Kernel)

The null space of a matrix is the set of solutions xxx﻿ to the homogenous system Ax=0⃗Ax=\vec0Ax=0﻿

Theorem 2

The null space of an m×nm \times nm×n﻿ matrix AAA﻿ is a subspace of Rn\R^nRn﻿ (dim⁡A\dim{A}dimA﻿).

Example: Let HHH﻿ be the set of all vectors in R4\R^4R4﻿ whose coordinates satisfy the equations a−2b+5c=da - 2b +5c = da−2b+5c=d﻿ and c−a=bc-a = bc−a=b﻿. Show that HHH﻿ is a subspace of R4\R^4R4﻿.

Column Space (Range)

The column space of an m×nm \times nm×n﻿ matrix AAA﻿, ColA\text{Col}{A}ColA﻿, is the set of all linear combinations of the columns of AAA﻿, which is a subspace of Rm\R^mRm﻿

Theorem 3

The column space of an m×nm\times nm×n﻿ matrix AAA﻿ is a subspace of Rm\R^mRm﻿. The Span of ppp﻿ vectors vvv﻿ from VVV﻿ is automatically a subspace of VVV﻿.

Row Space

The set of all linear combinations of the row vectors is called the row space of AAA﻿, RowA\text{Row}{A}RowA﻿, which is a subspace of Rn\R^nRn﻿

4.3 Bases

Theorem 4

An indexed set {v1,…,vp}\{v_1,\dots,v_p\}{v1​,…,vp​}﻿ of two or more vectors, with vq≠0v_q \neq 0vq​=0﻿, is linearly dependent if and only if some vjv_jvj​﻿ is a linear combination of the preceding vectors.

Basis

A set of vectors B\mathcal{B}B﻿ in VVV﻿ is a basis for HHH﻿ if the following two conditions are satisfied

  • B\mathcal{B}B﻿ is a linearly independent set
  • H=SpanBH = \text{Span}{\mathcal{B}}H=SpanB﻿

Theorem 5: The Spanning Set Theorem

Let S={v1,…,vp}S=\{v_1,\dots,v_p\}S={v1​,…,vp​}﻿ be a set in a vector space VVV﻿, and let H=Span{v1,…,vp}H=\text{Span}\{v_1,\dots,v_p\}H=Span{v1​,…,vp​}﻿

  • If vkv_kvk​﻿ in SSS﻿ is a linear combination of the remaining vectors, S−vkS-v_kS−vk​﻿ still spans HHH﻿
  • If H≠{0}H \neq \{0\}H={0}﻿, some subset of SSS﻿ is a basis for HHH﻿

Theorem 6

The pivot columns of a matrix AAA﻿ form a basis for ColA\text{Col}{A}ColA﻿.

Theorem 7

If two matrices AAA﻿ and BBB﻿ are row equivalent, then their row spaces are the same. If BBB﻿ is in echelon form, the nonzero rows of BBB﻿ form a basis for the row space of AAA﻿ and BBB﻿.

Example: Find a basis for the row space of AAA﻿

We find the basis for RowA\text{Row}ARowA﻿ by row-reducing to RREF. The pivot columns of AAA﻿ form the basis for RowA\text{Row}ARowA﻿.

4.5 The Dimension of a Vector Space

Theorem 10

If a vector space VVV﻿ has a basis B={b1,…,bn}\mathcal{B}=\{b_1,\dots,b_n\}B={b1​,…,bn​}﻿, then any set in VVV﻿ containing more than nnn﻿ vectors must be linearly dependent

Theorem 11

If a vector space VVV﻿ has a basis of nnn﻿ vectors, then every basis of VVV﻿ must consist of exactly nnn﻿ vectors.

Dimension

The dimension of a vector space, dim⁡V\dim VdimV﻿, is the number of vectors in a basis for VVV﻿. dim⁡{0⃗}=0\dim\{\vec 0\}=0dim{0}=0﻿

Example: Find the dimension of the subspace H={[a−3b+6c5a+4db−2c−d5d]}H = \left\{ \begin{bmatrix} a-3b+6c\\ 5a+4d\\ b-2c-d\\ 5d \end{bmatrix} \right\}H=⎩⎨⎧​​a−3b+6c5a+4db−2c−d5d​​⎭⎬⎫​﻿

First, we rewrite this set of linear equations as a linear combination of vectors

Now we row-reduce to RREF and find that the pivot columns correspond to the basis vectors which define dim⁡V\dim VdimV﻿

Theorem 12

Let HHH﻿ be a subspace of a finite-dimensional vector space VVV﻿. Any linearly independent set in HHH﻿ can be expanded to a basis for HHH﻿, where dim⁡H≤dim⁡V\dim{H} \leq \dim{V}dimH≤dimV﻿

Theorem 13: The Basis Theorem

Let VVV﻿ be a ppp﻿-dimensional vector space, p≥1p\geq 1p≥1﻿. Any linearly independent set of exactly ppp﻿ elements in VVV﻿ is automatically a basis for VVV﻿. Any set of exactly ppp﻿ elements that spans VVV﻿ is automatically a basis for VVV﻿

Rank and Nullity

The rank of an m×nm \times nm×n﻿ matrix AAA﻿ is the dimension of the column space (number of pivot columns) and the nullity of AAA﻿ is the dimension of the null space (number of free variables).

Theorem 14: The Rank Theorem

Thus, we can add the following properties to invertible matrices:

  • The columns of AAA﻿ form a basis for Rn\R^nRn﻿
  • ColA=Rn\text{Col}A = \R^nColA=Rn﻿
  • RankA=n\text{Rank}{A} =nRankA=n﻿
  • NulA={0}\text{Nul}{A} = \{0\}NulA={0}﻿
